author: FrenchguywholikesWiz
body:
Calls on Inuit. (INTU)

DD: So many assholes this year are going to file for capital gains and pay an extra $80 to Turbo Tax. Revenue is gonna smack. Buying long calls post election.

author: cranial_pudding
body:
Fuck it

Cathie take the wheel, I'm buying INTU and ICE because of you

author: derprondo
body:
How many of you autists are going to need Turbo Tax Premier this year instead of the basic?  If not Turbo Tax, how do you plan to file your 2020 taxes with hundreds of options trades?

I’m speculating that Intuit might see a large boost in Turbo Tax revenue this year from a lot more people needing the more expensive Turbo Tax features, such as importing data from your broker.

author: Kashm11r
body: I'll cut them some slack with some positives. They have over 3 times the money they need to service their existing debt which would allow them to sustain the net few years of operations without issue. They have a superior product to Microsoft and portfolio of services that appeal more to the user. Microsoft is only a serious threat because they can afford to provide Teams for free and subsidize that cost through their other revenue streams. Slack's current P/S ratio is under 23 and P/B ratio is under 21. They have a revenue retention rate of over 125% and target smaller businesses with greater appeal than Microsoft while still having a wide customer base among the large corporations including Shopify, IBM, Lyft, BBC, Intuit, Splunk, Fastly, RBC, Newscorp, Hubspot, TD Ameritrade, Vodafone, Target, Jet, Hello Fresh, NASA, Liberty Mutual, NBC, Buzzfeed, Turner, Nasdaq, Walmart, Nike, McKinsey, T-Mobile, Comcast, Airbnb, NY Times and many more. Ark Invest is bullish on this company and it is the 7th largest holding in their Inovation ETF and the 6th largest holding in their Next Generation Internet ETF. People may not like to root for the underdog when it comes to the stock market and monopolistic behemoth tech companies like Microsoft, but I like the idea of rooting for the smaller players with superior products and services that are trying to provide in a new market segment. Slack is also posting over 50% revenue growth this year and should post over 35% revenue growth next year.

author: Nope______________
body: Do you know how easy taxes are for 90% of the population? It’s a joke on how intuit and H&R Block are still in business

author: ravepeacefully
body: Most of them are free and open source, Ofx.net is the creator of the standardized format. Yodlee is one, intuit is another. None of them are small developer friendly unfortunately. There are surely TONS more, but not released to public. Plaid is by far the most friendly to small devs, but it’s still helllllllaa expensive.

author: Tuscaroraboy
body: Exactly. Intuit is aiming to be a one stop shop for all small business. Business Bank Account, loans, insurance.

author: The_Folkhero
body:
Here are five more big brand tech stocks for you to consider adding to your list:

Adobe - a "baby FAANG" that has more room to run, market cap-wise, than FAANG. 

Salesforce - same reason as Adobe above, baby FAANG. 

Intuit - under the radar, category killer with tax and accounting software 

Pinterest - scarce social media property that is adding e-commerce functionality soon with Shopify. 

Shopify - agnostic 3rd party seller platform that helped Kyle Jenner become almost a billionaire when she used Shopify to sell her beauty products and I think will be replicated with other influencers in the future. Shopify is the back office for anyone that wants to compete with Amazon. Shopify is signing partnerships left and right with the likes of Walmart, Facebook, Pinterest, Microsoft, etc, and will become even more pivotal once "social shopping" becomes the hot trend. Companies trust the agnostic platform that they have as opposed to Amazon that competes with it's 3rd party sellers and has been accused of fudging search results to favor Amazon products.

author: caseyrobinson2
body: Regarding Amzn and fb and intu in some ways they are monopolieis since they have so much market share in their industry, is it possible the government might break them up like what they said to standard oil, att and ibm before?

it's like she's speaking to us directly

author: ravepeacefully
body:
Do you really think plaid is unique? It’s an implementation of the open financial exchange. They are nowhere near the only company doing data aggregation. There will be 100 companies like plaid in 10 years. Intuit has their own data aggregation, many banks will hop in as well and most already have. 

The concept of the OFE is an amazing idea, but yeah plaid is just one implementation. Visa hella overpaid.

author: The_Folkhero
body:
Adobe - a "baby FAANG" that has more room to run, market cap-wise, than FAANG. 

Salesforce - same reason as Adobe above, baby FAANG. 

Intuit - under the radar, category killer with tax and accounting software that pays a dividend to boot. 

Pinterest - scarce social media property that is adding e-commerce functionality soon with Shopify. 

Shopify - agnostic 3rd party seller platform that helped Kyle Jenner become almost a billionaire when she used Shopify to sell her beauty products and I think will be replicated with other influencers in the future. Shopify is the back office for anyone that wants to compete with Amazon. Shopify is signing partnerships left and right with the likes of Walmart, Facebook, Pinterest, Microsoft, etc, and will become even more pivotal once "social shopping" becomes the hot trend. Companies trust the agnostic platform that they have as opposed to Amazon that competes with it's 3rd party sellers and has been accused of fudging search results to favor Amazon products.

Facebook - big now, but still enjoying 20% revenue growth. 

Sprout Social - social media management software platform.  A picks, pans and shovels play on the exponential growth of social media.

author: taiwansteez
body: I think it is a real possibility for AMZN if they continue expanding at the rate they did these last 10 years. I don't think FB faces that threat, although I do think the government might prevent some of their future acquisitions, they're not going to be able to buy another Instagram anytime soon. I'm not too worried about INTU because they don't attract a ton of attention. I also have a position in HRB but they are way behind in their software offerings
